question: Which equation describes flow from the groundwater system to the drain in a DRN boundary condition? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. The DRN flow equation is active only when groundwater system head is above the drain elevation.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. DRN flow is head-dependent and allows only outflow. There is no flow when groundwater  head is below the drain elevation.

question: Which parameter controls the magnitude of discharge through the DRN boundary? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Good job. DRN discharge is governed by conductance and head difference. Drain elevation controls magnitude of flow in that if it is above the groundwater head, then flow is zero
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. Flow depends on conductance and head difference and the threshold elevation — not porosity.

question: When is the DRN boundary inactive in a MODFLOW simulation? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. The DRN boundary does not discharge unless $h_{gw} >= H_{D}$. and conductance is greater than zero
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. Flow only occurs when groundwater head is above the drain elevation and conductance is greater than zero.

question: Which conditions can cause a DRN boundary to remove too much water from the model? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Exactly. Poor parameterization of DRNs can lead to over-drainage.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. An excess outflow problem usually is due to errors in conductance or elevation settings. The drain diameter is not considered by DRN, though it may be considered when you estimate conductance.

question: What is the conceptual analogy for a DRN boundary in a field setting? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Nicely done. DRNs model seepage drains like ditches or tile drains, as well as tunnels and open pit mines, but not rivers or impermeable materials.
error: ❌  Some of your choices are not correct. DRNs model seepage drains like ditches or tile drains, as well as tunnels and open pit mines, but not rivers or impermeable materials.

question: Why does the Q–h plot for a DRN boundary become horizontal if the head is below the drain elevation? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. The flat region reflects zero discharge when the head is below the elevation threshold.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. The flat part of the Q–h plot reflects zero discharge when $h_{gw} \leq H_{D}$. Flow is not constant at a drain boundary and the head does not influence the value of conductance.
